headline.main: Enron, the Supreme Court and Shareholders on the Brink
headline.print_headline: Enron, the Supreme Court and Shareholders on the Brink

docs.snippet: First came the books, then the television docudramas and feature-length films. And now ''Enron: The Musical.'' Opening on Friday on a stage way, way off Broadway -- at Lambert Hall in Houston -- the revue is a send-up of the rise and fall of the i...
docs.lead_paragraph: First came the books, then the television docudramas and feature-length films. And now ''Enron: The Musical.'' Opening on Friday on a stage way, way off Broadway -- at Lambert Hall in Houston -- the revue is a send-up of the rise and fall of the infamous energy company. In two acts, six local actors each play up to 10 roles, including those of the former chief executives Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, and the former finance chief Andrew S. Fastow. The songs are show-tune parodies -- ''Thank Heaven for Off The Books Deals,'' for example, instead of ''Thank Heaven for Little Girls.'' The writer-director-producer is Mark Fraser, whose day job is selling janitorial supplies.

headline.main: First Time as Tragedy, Second as a Musical

headline.main: D.O.J. Seeks Broader Fraud Law to Cover Self-Dealing

docs.snippet: The Supreme Court will hear arguments Monday on whether the conviction of Jeffrey Skilling, former chief executive of Enron, should be overturned because the prejudice against him in Houston was so strong and pervasive that he could not receive a ...
docs.lead_paragraph: When Enron collapsed in 2001, thousands of employees at its Houston headquarters lost their jobs and savings, and the city's economy reeled. Much of the public's anger was directed at Jeffrey K. Skilling, the company's former chief executive, Adam Liptak reports in The New York Times.
docs.abstract: The Supreme Court will hear arguments Monday on whether the conviction of Jeffrey Skilling, former chief executive of Enron, should be overturned because the prejudice against him in Houston was so strong and pervasive that he could not receive a fair trial.
